content.description:
Climb the prominent white, crack-riddled pillar to a perfect belay ledge (5.9). Continue past 1 bolt and various cracks and flakes to the base of a long, thin seam up a sheer wall (5.10a). Climb the long seam until it shuts; continue left past 1 bolt, to another crack system, continue to belay ledge below the headwall - a long pitch (5.10d). Climb past 3 bolts and some small cam placements, traversing up and right to gain a large hanging corner; scramble right on easy ledges with a few moves to belay below final wall (5.10c). Climb easy cracks up final wall to the top (5.8).

Details:  bellacoolatrails.ca/content…



Snootli ice rink parking.

Mixed protection, double rack to 1", a couple larger pieces, bring many small wires and cams for pitch 3.

Start below a large, white flake; climb past 1 bolt and discontinuous cracks to a belay ledge below a friendly crack (5.8). Climb the friendly crack, traverse right and face climb past 3 bolts into the main corner system to a small belay ledge below a thin crack (5.10b). Climb past 1 bolt into a thin seam, slowly expanding into a finger crack before disappearing; face climb up and right past 3 bolts, navigating small roof features (5.10d). Finish up friendly flakes and cracks past a small roof, then head out right past 2 bolts to belay anchors at top of the wall (5.8) - sometimes wet.

Details:  bellacoolatrails.ca/content…



Start from Snootli ice rink parking.

Mixed protection, double rack to 1.5", bring small wires for pitch 3.

A moderate 5-pitch gear climb on Snootli's west walls. Start at the far left side of the west wall, at the base of an ivory white pillar with several attractive flakes. Climb the white flake system to easier ground and belay at the base of a compact triple-corner system (5.8). Climb the columns/cracks to easier ground and belay at the beginning of a large, low-angle open-book corner (5.9). Choose from a variety of corner (more vegetation) and face cracks (cleaner, less protection) until exiting the corner left to the obvious blunt arete via a series of flakes up the left-hand wall. Follow the arete up to a belay (5.9). Continue on up and slightly left over easy ground to belay near the base of smooth-sided corner (5.6). Finish up the enjoyable and friendly corner, past a few face moves to final belay (5.9).

Details:  bellacoolatrails.ca/content…



Snootli ice rink parking lot

Good climbing with good protection over interesting features with fine positions. Bring rack to 2"

climbs.name: Eastern Medicine
climbs.fa: FA 2020 Devon Girard, Grant McCartney, Peter Wainswright

content.description:
Multipitch up the ~750m Snootli East face. Many excellent pitches on fine rock, some runouts on easier ground but well protected where you need it. First 1/4 is almost a route on its own, gaining a 200m pillar feature in 4 long and substaintial pitches. Difficulty eases after that for the majority of the route, with a nice sting in the tail on the final pitch. Bring 70m lead rope for climbing. 60m ropes will get you down. ~90 min approach

https://bellacoolatrails.ca/content/eastern-medicine Double rack to 2", triples or quadruples of small sizes (Metolius #0 and #1), small wires. 3" gear useful but not required.

climbs.name: Open Sourcery
climbs.fa: 2020 Devon Girard, Peter Wainwright, Grant McCartney, Steve Hodgeson, Rob Nelson, Pat Moser

content.description:
A 15-pitch adventure up the grand NW face, starting up the giant dihedral between the starts of Spirit Walker and Snakes n Ladders, and topping out above the large upper tree island near the top of the wall. It is also possible to exit left after pitch 13, and gain the same upper helm feature as Spirit Walker (just from the right). Mix of gear and bolts.

Details:  bellacoolatrails.ca/content…

Pitch 1 - 5.10- (or 5.5 bypass): From gear belay at base of waterfall, climb the face and thin cracks directly above to the base of the main dihedral. Alternately, or when main face is wet, bypass to the right on easy but runout friction.
Pitch 2 - 5.9: Climb the dihedral with glorious laybacking, stemming, jamming and more to anchors halfway up the corner system.
Pitch 3 - 5.10+: Continue up the corner for a few meters before breaking left around the arete on an obvious ramp. Continue face climbing near the arete past a bolt and to the right of a roof feature. Step left and reach around, bypassing the roof using hand cracks. A few more crack moves gains easy ledges and anchors.
Pitch 4 - 5.10+: Face climbing past a few bolts to a small seam, some small pro, and anchors.
Pitch 5 - 5.10-: Gain a left-leaning face crack to easier ledges; scramble up easy ground to the right to anchors.
Pitch 6 - 5.10-: Face climb to the right of a thin seam past a few bolts; rejoin the seam for a few moves and another bolt, then traverse right to the top of a large flake and anchors.
Pitch 7 - 5.10: Face climb left past bolts to a large half-moon feature; easy climbing within the moon feature to gain a belay on the left edge.
Pitch 8 - 5.10: Exit the half-moon left past a bolt; climb the mix of friction and flake past several more bolts to a belay immediately left of the large diagonal vegetated streak that clefts Snootli's NW face.
Pitch 9 - 5.10: Cross the diagonal fault and gain the right-hand wall with some difficulty. Face climb past several sets of bolts; some harder climbing punctuated by easy sections.
Pitch 10 - 5.10+: A gem of a pitch, up a steep flake right off the belay and then face climbing past bolts zigzagging through large dish features.
Pitch 11 - 5.10: Friction traverse left past a bolt, then face climb up to a slabby ledge; traverse left past 2 more bolts to an airy belay below the looming pillar and crack system.
Pitch 12 - 5.10+: Climb the widening crack up the headwall past a couple bolts and much gear. Turn the lip and friction climb to a beautiful belay stance.
Pitch 12.5 - 5.5: Climb 20m over very easy ground to anchors at the base of a steep rolling slab.
Pitch 13 - 5.10: Climb the shut seam, scrounging for small gear, to a pair of bolts trending right - a bit runout. Continue up to a relic 1/4" bolt with handmade hanger; clip it for good luck and then choose whether to exit left to the Spirit Walker anchors or continue right past another bolt to anchors below a water groove.
Pitch 14 - 5.6: Climb the runout but very easy and asthetic water groove, trending right.
Pitch 15 - 5.6: Drift right along several easy grooves, then up a short watercourse of sorts to a wide slabby alcove at the base of a wall to the left. Final anchors on the left edge of this wall.

Explore the upper slabs or exit directly right, into the trees and down the descent trail. Or rap the route.

Route was a collaboration of many over the years; pitches added or first climbed by Grant McCartney, Steve Hodgeson, Rob Nelson, Pat Moser, Peter Wainwright, Devon Girard



Snootli ice rink parking lot

Mix of gear and bolts. Double rack to 2" and something for 3", 12-16 draws. Bring some small wires for the occasional key placement. All stations have bolted rap rings. Pitches up to 60m.

The original route on Snootli.

Ray with various partners put up Snootli Express in the 1990s as a very runout climb. The first couple pitches had a couple bolts per pitch then it was a long series of full pitches, station to station with 0 or 1 piece of gear per pitch. The two crux pitches up high were a totally unprotected 10a and then a 10b with 1 bolt at the crux. Head spinning climbing!

Then it wasn't getting enough traffic so he rebolted it into a multi pitch sport climb and renamed it Spirit Walker.

I haven't climbed the rebolted version but I hear you can expect ~10 bolts per pitch.

Original description: 3.5 pitches up slabs and corners aiming for the right side of the prominent tree island ledge. From there, muliple pitches at moderate grades (low 5th to 5,8) straight up, beautiful clean climbing on patina edges. The original crux pitches were the 11th and 12th (10a  pockets to slab to a seam, 10b stemming to boulder move). From there three more ~5.5 pitches reach the top of the wall.

You might find mention of inflated grades up to 5.11 for this climb but trust me, at the time I climbed it 10b was about as hard as I could climb.

Despite the length it's a fast climb because you just go, no need to hunt for gear.



Head uphill along the trail from the ice rink.Starts almost exactly where the trail meets the wall

Rack of draws, maybe some supplemental gear nowadays?

600-700m granite slab, currently 8 multipitches from 4-16 pitches, 5.9-5.11. Also a crag lower down with ~20 routes, and a bouldering area. 
  
 For more information see  bellacoolatrails.ca/climbing
